text.value: Problem : Write a program to place the numbers 1 to 12 as if they were on a clock face.;
# Write a program to place the numbers 1 to 12 as ;
# if they were on a clock face. ;
num_x, num_y = end_point( x_centre, y_centre, radius, angle ) ;
Problem: Draw 10 parallel horizontal lines, each 100 long, starting at (10,10) and spaced 10 apart, going downwards.;
# Write a program to draw 10 parallel horizontal lines,;
# each 100 long, spaced 10 apart. First line starts at (10,10);
y = 10 # This is the value changing on each loop;
They should both take a list of words and they should both check each word
to see if the first letter is upper or lower case. ;
For any word that has a lowercase first letter, the first letter should be converted to upper case.;
The first function should create and return a new list containing all the words, and the ;
second function should change words in place in the list - it does not need to return anything.;
This is a rough plan for the body of the functions;
for each word in the list;
if the word does not start with a capital letter;
change it so that it does start with a capital;
# function to create and return a list containing all;
# words in supplied list, ensuring all have capitalised;
# function to capitalise first letter of all words in;
for wordIndex in range( len( words ) ):;
# Generate the characteristics of the new line;
endX, endY = end_point( startX, startY, sideLength, angle );
# Now get ready for next line;

Write a program to draw a random segmented line. More precisely, the line should start at (100, 100) and consist of 10 straight segments, connected so that the end of the first line joins up with the start of the second, and so on, to form one long line. The length and orientation of each segment should be chosen at random, between the limits 0-50 and 0-359 respectively.;
# Draw a random segmented lines. 10 segments, end of one joined to;
# start of the next, each a random length (between 0-50) and orientation.;
# Generate the characteristics of the new line;
endX, endY = end_point( startX, startY, newLength, newAngle );
# Now get ready for next line;
# Function to draw a regular shape, given starting point,;
# number of sides and side length.;
# Generate the characteristics of the new line;
endX, endY = end_point( startX, startY, sideLength, angle );
# Now get ready for next line;
Be sure to read what is in the bottom pane of the window on every step.;
to check whether a password conforms to a set of rules ? as might be used when you register with a website. The function should
take as parameter the password as a string
return True or False depending on whether the password is well-formed or not, respectively
. The rules for a valid password are as follows:;
- Must contain at least one digit, one lower case letter and one upper case letter;
The following are some sample passwords and the expected output from the checker function:;
# Function to check if a password is well-formed, that is;
# contains at least 6 characters with at least one of each of;
# a digit, a lowercase letter and an uppercase letter.;
# Check if the length is ok;
# Test on whether length is ok;
# Check each character in turn in the password;
# Combine our analysis into a single boolean value and return it;
result = lengthOK and hasLowerLetter and hasUpperLetter and hasDigit;
return lengthOK and hasLowerLetter and hasUpperLetter and hasDigit;

The Just A Minute program on BBC Radio 4 asks contestants to speak on a specific topic for one minute. Among other conditions, they must not use any word more than once. To help the game show hosts, the BBC has asked you to
reads in a single line of text from the user
, representing whatever the contestant said, and
writing out any words that appear more than once in the text.;
For example, if the contestant said, on the topic The Ides of March:;

The Ides of March are well known historically as the date on which Julius Caesar was assassinated by Brutus and others. To be precise, the day of the year in question is the 15th of March. JC should have known better as Shakespeare?s soothsayer apparently warned him of the danger, saying Beware the Ides of March.;
the programme should write out the following: ;
Note that the order in which the words appear in the output is not important and that upper and lower case are treated the same - see how 'The' and 'the' are treated the same in the example above.;
# Checker suitable for a game such as Just a Minute;
# Checks for repeated words in a sentence;
text = raw_input( "Please enter the text to be checked: " );
# Turn the raw text into a list of words;
# Scan over the word list, keeping a count of each word seen;
# Use a dictionary to keep the word counts;
# Create a new entry for this word, not seen before;
# Only write out words seen more than once;

In the Lab Exam before Christmas, you had to write code to remove stop words from sentences. The following function, remove_stop_words, is designed to take as parameter a list of words and then return a copy of the list with any occurrences of the stop words given in stop_word_list removed. ;
The function contains four errors. Identify each error precisely, explaining both the problem and how you would fix it. Use the comment numbers to refer to particular lines.;
# Example stop word list only, obviously too short;

1. Do your best to understand how the code is meant to be working. This is usually explained to a greater or lesser extent in the problem itself. As you do this, you may well encounter problems. If not, then look at the rest of the points.;
2. Are all the variables initialised properly? That is, is any variable used BEFORE it has first been given a value?;
3. In loops, check that the loop will "go round" the right number of times. Take care to check on the initialisation, test for completion of the loop, and update, of any stepper/counter variable;

4. Check tests in if statements and while loops. Are you sure the test is the correct one? Compound Boolean expressions, where you are using more than one ?and? or ?or? operator, can often be used incorrectly.;
5. In Python, indentation is important. Is every statement at the correct indentation level? It is easy to miss this, so look carefully.;
6. Are the computations required by the problem being performed correctly? This isn't just arithmetic operations - are all the boolean and string and list and dictionary operations correct?;
1. The variable words is not initialised. It is a gatherer variable, and should be initialised to the empty list. To fix it, between line 2 and 3, at one indentation level in, add ;

2. The test in the if statement in Line 4 is wrong. We should be testing for whether the current word we?re looking at is NOT in the stopword list ? only then do we add it to our new list. Change the line to:;

3. The return statement is not indented correctly. Just now the function will return the first time a valid word is found. It should be moved out to the same indentation as the for loop header - that is, it should only be executed once the for loop is finished.;
4. The update to the words variable on line 5 is incorrect. A word is being added to a list, but only lists can be added to lists. The line should read:;
A door entry system is monitoring access to a building. Every time sometime tries to enter the building by swiping their id card, the door entry system will call a subprogram
taking the id from the card as parameter
whether the person should be permitted to enter.;
Assume the subprogram can access a global variable containing an existing array of authorised users' ids.;
a) Write a general specification for the subprogram.;
b) Write the subprogram itself in a language of your choice.;
- assume this is a string, since no information given
true if the supplied id is authorised to enter
search through the authorised users' array to see if the supplied
an array of strings of authorised users, called authUsers
# Function to check whether a given id is in an array ;
FUNCTION permitEntry( STRING personId ) RETURNS BOOLEAN;
<action to take when we find a match>;
# Function to determine if user supplied as parameter;
# This is an example array of ids for authorised users, for testing;
# Use linear search to see if 'personId' is in 'authUsers';
# Action to take when we find a match;
The Door Entry problem has been extended. The system now keeps track of all attempts to access the building, in an array called
. Each entry in this array is a
dictionary that has a "user" field, this is the user id of the person who tried to enter, and a "success" field, this is a Boolean indicating whether the attempt to enter was successful or not
. An example dictionary for a successful entry by the user with id "k342" is:;
id of a user as parameter
returns the number of times that user has successfully entered
a) Write a general specification for the subprogram.;
b) Write the subprogram itself in Python.;
the person id - as before, this is a string
an integer, the count of successful entries for the supplied user
search through the attempts array counting occurrences of dictionaries with the supplied user as the user, and noting a successful entry.
all given in the question this time
# This is an example array of entry attempts, useful for testing;
# Function to count number of successful entries by the supplied user;
# Use typical count occurrences template to count successful entries;
# Test to decide whether to count this one;
The Door Entry problem has been extended. The system now keeps track of all attempts to access the building, in an
. Each entry in this array is a

value of a record type that has a "user" field, this is the user id of the person who tried to enter, and a "success" field, this is a Boolean indicating whether the attempt to enter was successful or not
. The record type is defined as follows:;
RECORD Attempt IS { STRING user, BOOLEAN success };
id of a user as parameter
returns the number of times that user has successfully entered
a) Write a general specification for the subprogram.;
b) Write the subprogram itself in Python.;
the person id - as before, this is a string
an integer, the count of successful entries for the supplied user
search through the attempts array counting occurrences of dictionaries with the supplied user as the user, and noting a successful entry.
all given in the question this time;
RECORD Attempt IS { STRING user, BOOLEAN success };
# This is an example array of entry attempts, useful for testing;
# Function to count number of successful entries by the supplied user;
FUNCTION countEntries( STRING personId ) RETURNS INTEGER;
# Use typical count occurrences template to count successful entries;
FOR EACH attempt FROM attempts DO;
<Test to decide whether to count this one>
